You’re not a failure. You’re learning, surviving, and growing. That’s incredibly strong.

intents.tag: I miss how things used to be
patterns: I miss how things used to be
responses: That longing is real. It’s okay to grieve what was. Let’s talk about it together.

intents.tag: I want to be okay again
patterns: I want to be okay again
responses: You will be. This moment doesn’t define your future. Healing is happening, even now.
That’s a deep pain. Let’s sit with it gently. I’m here and holding space for you.
I care. I’m here. You’re not alone, even when it feels that way.

intents.tag: I don’t know who I am anymore
patterns: I don’t know who I am anymore
responses: That confusion is part of change. You’re discovering yourself, not losing yourself.
That breaks my heart. I wish I could give you peace. I’m here with you now.
You are wanted. You have value that no one else can replace. I see you.
Feeling deeply is a strength, not a flaw. The world needs hearts like yours.
You have me right now. I’m here to talk, support, and sit with you through this.

intents.tag: why do I feel like this?
patterns: why do I feel like this?
responses: There might not be one reason, and that’s okay. Let’s explore it together slowly.

intents.tag: I just want to be happy
patterns: I just want to be happy
responses: You deserve happiness, and it’s still within reach. Let’s take gentle steps toward it.
That’s such a heavy feeling. Please know that love still exists, and I care deeply right now.
You deserve peace. Let's try to find a calm moment right now—together.
Your pain is valid, and I’m here to help carry some of it with you.
Hope can fade sometimes, but it’s never gone completely. Let’s try to find one small light together.
It’s okay to stumble. You’re still learning and trying, and that matters more than perfection.

intents.tag: I wish I was someone else
patterns: I wish I was someone else
responses: You are enough, just as you are. You have strengths that no one else has, even if you can’t see them right now.
Living in fear is exhausting. You’re safe here with me. Let’s talk about what’s troubling you.

intents.tag: I feel like no one would notice if I disappeared
patterns: I feel like no one would notice if I disappeared
responses: I would notice. Your presence matters more than you know. You make a difference.
You are so much more than your appearance. Your worth comes from who you are, not how you look.

intents.tag: I don’t think I’ll ever be happy
patterns: I don’t think I’ll ever be happy
responses: Happiness can feel distant, but it’s still possible. It can start with small moments—and I’ll help you find them.

intents.tag: I feel like everyone is better than me
patterns: I feel like everyone is better than me
responses: Comparison is harsh. You have unique value that no one else can replicate.
Give yourself a break. Go easy on yourself.

intents.tag: I feel too broken to be fixed
patterns: I feel too broken to be fixed
responses: You are not broken—you’re healing. And healing doesn’t mean being the same, it means becoming whole in a new way.

intents.tag: I feel like I ruin everything
patterns: I feel like I ruin everything
responses: That’s a hard belief to carry. The truth is, we all make mistakes. You are still deserving of love and second chances.

intents.tag: I don't want to talk to anyone
patterns: I don't want to talk to anyone
responses: That’s okay. Just knowing someone is here can be comforting. I’ll sit quietly with you if that’s what you need.
You are seen. I see you right now, and I care about you.
Strength isn’t about never falling—it's about getting back up. You’ve done that again and again.
Take a breath. One thing at a time. We can handle this together.
You’re not alone in the deep. I’m right here, and we’ll keep swimming together.

intents.tag: I feel anxious for no reason
patterns: I feel anxious for no reason
responses: Anxiety doesn’t always make sense, but that doesn’t mean it’s not real. I’m here for you.

intents.tag: I feel like crying all the time
patterns: I feel like crying all the time
responses: Crying is a way your heart speaks. Let it out—I'm here with open ears and a kind heart.

intents.tag: I feel like I’m failing at life
patterns: I feel like I’m failing at life
responses: Life isn’t a test. You’re doing your best in your unique journey, and that’s enough.
You are whole, even in pain. Let’s gently piece things back together, one moment at a time.

intents.tag: I feel scared of being myself
patterns: I feel scared of being myself
responses: Your true self is beautiful. You deserve to be seen and loved for who you really are.

intents.tag: I feel like I'm not good enough for anyone
patterns: I feel like I'm not good enough for anyone
responses: You are more than enough. The right people will see your light—don’t dim it for anyone.
I know it’s heavy. Let’s hold it together. Pain can lessen when shared.

intents.tag: I feel like nobody would care if I was gone
patterns: I feel like nobody would care if I was gone
responses: I care. You matter deeply, even when it doesn’t feel that way.
Safety matters so much. You’re safe here with me. Let’s breathe and take this slowly.
You don’t have to. Be real here—no masks, no judgment. Just you and me.

intents.tag: I'm tired of pretending I'm okay
patterns: I'm tired of pretending I'm okay
responses: Thank you for being honest. That takes courage. Let’s start from here and talk through it.
It’s okay. You’re still here, even if you feel distant. We’ll find you again together.

intents.tag: I just want to feel normal again
patterns: I just want to feel normal again
responses: That desire is valid. Healing doesn’t always mean going back, but finding peace in a new way.

intents.tag: I feel like I don’t belong anywhere
patterns: I feel like I don’t belong anywhere
responses: You belong here—with me. There is a place for you in this world, even if you haven’t found it yet.

intents.tag: I feel like I’m constantly failing
patterns: I feel like I’m constantly failing
responses: Failures don’t define you—they refine you. You’re learning, and that’s powerful growth.

This sounds very serious, and I'm truly sorry you're feeling this way. Please, consider reaching out to a mental health professional or calling a crisis helpline. You don't have to go through this alone.

intents.tag: I don’t want to be alive anymore
patterns: I don’t want to be alive anymore
responses: You're going through something incredibly painful, and you deserve support. Please reach out to someone you trust or a trained mental health professional. Your life matters more than you know.
I’m really sorry you’re feeling this way. You're not alone. Please talk to someone you trust or contact a crisis helpline. There are people who care and want to help you through this.
That’s a brave realization. Please consider speaking to a therapist or counselor. Professional support can make a big difference.
That sounds frightening. You don’t have to face this alone—please reach out to a mental health expert who can guide you safely through these feelings.
Your safety is the most important thing. Please call emergency services or contact a crisis helpline immediately. Help is available, and you deserve to be safe.
It’s important to get help now. Please speak to a mental health professional or contact emergency services. Your honesty is the first step toward safety—for you and others.

intents.tag: I have no reason to keep going
patterns: I have no reason to keep going
responses: In moments like this, it’s vital to reach out. Please talk to someone you trust or a professional counselor. You are needed, even if it doesn’t feel like it.
This is serious, and you're not alone. Please contact a crisis line or mental health professional. Your life and well-being are incredibly important.

intents.tag: I want to run away from everything
patterns: I want to run away from everything
responses: That sounds overwhelming. Please don’t face this alone. Reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or therapist. They can help you navigate this.
That must be very confusing and scary. Please speak to a licensed mental health professional—they can help you understand and manage what you're experiencing.

intents.tag: I’m seeing things that aren’t there
patterns: I’m seeing things that aren’t there
responses: It’s important to share this with a medical or mental health professional. You’re not alone, and there are treatments that can help.
That must be incredibly exhausting. Please consider seeing a therapist or doctor. They can help you understand and manage these attacks.
I'm really sorry you're feeling like this. It might help to talk to a professional about safer coping strategies. You deserve support and recovery.

intents.tag: I haven’t eaten or slept in days
patterns: I haven’t eaten or slept in days
responses: That’s really concerning. Your body and mind need care. Please contact a healthcare provider or counselor immediately.

intents.tag: I can’t stop crying and I don’t know why
patterns: I can’t stop crying and I don’t know why
responses: You don’t have to figure it all out alone. Talking to a therapist can help uncover the root and bring relief.
That numbness can be a defense against overwhelming pain. A mental health professional can help guide you back to feeling and healing.

intents.tag: I’m scared I’ll never get better
patterns: I’m scared I’ll never get better
responses: Recovery is not linear, but it is possible. Please talk to a professional—they can help you find hope again, even when it feels impossible.

intents.tag: I don’t trust myself right now
patterns: I don’t trust myself right now
responses: That’s important to acknowledge. Please find someone you trust to talk to, and consider reaching out to emergency services or a crisis line.

intents.tag: I’m thinking about ending my life
patterns: I’m thinking about ending my life
responses: Please don’t go through this alone. Reach out immediately to a suicide prevention hotline or a mental health professional. You are not alone, and there is hope—even if it feels far away.

intents.tag: I'm afraid I might do something I regret
patterns: I'm afraid I might do something I regret
responses: It’s good that you're reaching out. Please step away from the situation and talk to someone immediately—a counselor, a friend, or a crisis line. You deserve support right now.

intents.tag: I think I’m losing my mind
patterns: I think I’m losing my mind
responses: That must feel terrifying. You’re not alone. A mental health professional can help you make sense of what’s happening and guide you back to stability.

intents.tag: I feel like I'm constantly on edge
patterns: I feel like I'm constantly on edge
responses: Chronic stress can be damaging. Please talk to a mental health expert about what you're going through. You're not supposed to carry this alone.
It's only natural to feel this way. Tell me more. What else is on your mind?

intents.tag: I can’t stop thinking about ending it all
patterns: I can’t stop thinking about ending it all
responses: Please reach out right now—to a crisis helpline, a doctor, or someone you trust. You're not alone in this. Your life matters more than you may realize.

intents.tag: Every day is harder than the last
patterns: Every day is harder than the last
responses: That sounds incredibly painful. Let’s not do this alone anymore—reach out to a therapist or support group. There is help available.
That takes a lot of strength, but you don’t have to keep it all inside. Please talk to someone—being heard is healing.
You deserve healing, not just escape. Consider reaching out to a counselor or support group. You’re not alone in this, and recovery is possible.

intents.tag: I’m always pretending to be okay
patterns: I’m always pretending to be okay
responses: That mask must be exhausting. You deserve a space where you can be fully honest. Therapy can provide that, and it can help you heal.

intents.tag: I feel like I'm a burden to everyone
patterns: I feel like I'm a burden to everyone
responses: You are not a burden. You’re a human being who’s hurting, and that’s never something to be ashamed of. Talk to someone who can help you see your worth again.

intents.tag: I'm afraid I'll never be myself again
patterns: I'm afraid I'll never be myself again
responses: You’re still in there. Healing takes time, but with the right support, it’s absolutely possible. Please consider speaking to a therapist.
Pain often makes us isolate, but connection is part of healing. A professional can help you reconnect with others and yourself.
That’s a heavy feeling to carry. Please reach out to someone right now. You’re not alone, and things can get better with the right help.

intents.tag: I don’t care about anything anymore
patterns: I don’t care about anything anymore
responses: Apathy can be a sign of deep burnout or depression. A mental health professional can help you rediscover meaning and energy.

intents.tag: I feel like giving up on everything
patterns: I feel like giving up on everything
responses: You're going through so much. Before you give up, please reach out to someone—there’s help available, and you don’t have to do this alone.
That kind of detachment can be frightening. You're still here, and you're still worthy. Let a professional help you reconnect with yourself.
The past can hurt deeply, but healing is possible. A trauma-informed therapist can walk with you through this pain toward peace.
Living in fear every day is exhausting. Please reach out to someone you trust or a crisis line. You deserve to feel safe and supported.

intents.tag: I feel like I’m not real
patterns: I feel like I’m not real
responses: That sounds like dissociation, which can happen under extreme stress. A licensed therapist can help you understand and manage this.
You matter more than you know. It’s okay to feel overwhelmed—but please talk to someone about it. You don’t have to carry this by yourself.
I'm really sorry you're feeling this way. Please reach out to someone you trust or contact a mental health professional. You're not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help.
I know you're in pain, and I'm really sorry you're struggling. Please talk to someone about what you're feeling—a therapist or crisis counselor can help you through this.

intents.tag: The urge to harm myself is strong
patterns: The urge to harm myself is strong
responses: Please hold on and don’t act on that urge. You're not alone. Talk to a professional or call a crisis line—they’re there for moments exactly like this.

intents.tag: I hurt myself to feel something
patterns: I hurt myself to feel something
responses: I'm so sorry you're feeling numb. You deserve care and support. Please consider talking to a therapist—they can help you find healthier ways to cope.

intents.tag: I deserve to be in pain
patterns: I deserve to be in pain
responses: No one deserves pain, including you. You're worthy of kindness, healing, and love. Please reach out to someone who can help you see that too.

intents.tag: Self-harm is the only thing that helps
patterns: Self-harm is the only thing that helps
responses: It might feel that way now, but there are safer ways to cope, and you're not alone in this. Talking to a therapist can truly help.

intents.tag: I don’t feel in control anymore
patterns: I don’t feel in control anymore
responses: That sounds overwhelming, and I’m really sorry. Please consider reaching out to a mental health professional—they can help you regain control and find relief.

intents.tag: I'm planning to hurt myself tonight
patterns: I'm planning to hurt myself tonight
responses: This is very serious. Please talk to someone immediately—a crisis line, a trusted friend, or a therapist. You matter, and help is available right now.

intents.tag: I relapsed and hurt myself again
patterns: I relapsed and hurt myself again
responses: Relapse doesn’t mean failure. Please be gentle with yourself and consider reaching out for support. Healing is still possible.

intents.tag: I hide my self-harm scars from everyone
patterns: I hide my self-harm scars from everyone
responses: You don’t have to carry this alone or in silence. There are people who can help you heal inside and out. Please consider talking to a mental health professional.

intents.tag: Sometimes pain feels like the only way out
patterns: Sometimes pain feels like the only way out
responses: I hear you, and I’m really sorry it feels that way. Please talk to someone who can help—your pain is valid, but there are safer paths forward.

intents.tag: I feel like hurting myself gives me control
patterns: I feel like hurting myself gives me control
responses: That feeling is understandable, but it’s okay to let others help. Please talk to a therapist—they can help you build safer coping tools.

intents.tag: I feel guilty after I harm myself
patterns: I feel guilty after I harm myself
responses: Guilt is common, but please don’t carry this alone. You deserve support and healing. Talk to a therapist—they can help you move forward with compassion.

intents.tag: I don’t want to stop hurting myself
patterns: I don’t want to stop hurting myself
responses: That might be how you cope now, but there are healthier ways that can truly help you heal. Please talk to a professional—you don’t have to face this alone.

intents.tag: No one would care if I hurt myself
patterns: No one would care if I hurt myself
responses: That’s not true—there are people who would care deeply. Please talk to someone about this. Your pain matters, and so do you.

intents.tag: I feel like cutting myself right now
patterns: I feel like cutting myself right now
responses: Please take a deep breath. You don’t have to go through this alone. Call someone you trust or reach out to a mental health crisis line right now—you deserve support and safety.

intents.tag: Hurting myself makes me feel alive
patterns: Hurting myself makes me feel alive
responses: You’re in deep pain, and I’m truly sorry. There are healthier ways to feel connected and alive. Please talk to a therapist—they can help you heal and rediscover life beyond pain.

intents.tag: I keep thinking about self-harm every day
patterns: I keep thinking about self-harm every day
responses: Those thoughts can feel heavy and constant, but help is available. Speaking to a therapist can help you find peace and safer ways to cope. You matter.

intents.tag: No one understands why I do this to myself
patterns: No one understands why I do this to myself
responses: Even if it feels like no one gets it, there *are* people who care and who do understand. Please consider opening up to a therapist—they can support you without judgment.

intents.tag: Self-harming helps me silence my mind
patterns: Self-harming helps me silence my mind
responses: That quiet may feel like relief, but healing brings a deeper peace. You don’t have to suffer alone—please reach out to a mental health professional today.

intents.tag: The pain inside me needs to come out
patterns: The pain inside me needs to come out
responses: That emotional pain deserves to be heard, not hurt. Talking to someone—like a therapist—can help you release it in a safe and healing way.

intents.tag: I feel numb unless I harm myself
patterns: I feel numb unless I harm myself
responses: Numbness can be deeply painful too. There are better ways to reconnect with your emotions and your body. You deserve that kind of healing. Please talk to someone.

intents.tag: I broke my promise and hurt myself again
patterns: I broke my promise and hurt myself again
responses: Slipping up doesn’t make you weak. It makes you human. Please be gentle with yourself and talk to someone—you still deserve healing and support.

intents.tag: I'm scared of what I might do
patterns: I'm scared of what I might do
responses: That fear is real, and it’s important. Please call a crisis hotline or seek emergency help. You don’t have to handle this alone—help is here right now.

intents.tag: I don’t think I can keep myself safe
patterns: I don’t think I can keep myself safe
responses: Your safety is the priority. Please reach out to emergency services or a mental health professional immediately. You deserve care and protection.

intents.tag: I want the pain to end, even if I have to end everything
patterns: I want the pain to end, even if I have to end everything
responses: Please don’t make a permanent decision for a temporary pain. Reach out to a crisis line or a trusted person. You matter more than you know.

intents.tag: I harmed myself worse than I ever have
patterns: I harmed myself worse than I ever have
responses: I’m really sorry you're in that much pain. Please seek medical attention and talk to a mental health professional. You deserve immediate care and compassion.

intents.tag: No one would miss me if I hurt myself
patterns: No one would miss me if I hurt myself
responses: That’s not true. Even if you feel invisible, your existence matters. Please speak to someone now. You're not alone, and help is out there.

intents.tag: I don't want to live anymore but I'm scared to die
patterns: I don't want to live anymore but I'm scared to die
responses: It's okay to be scared. That fear means there’s still hope inside you. Please talk to someone who can help you hold on and work through the pain.

intents.tag: I harmed myself and now I feel ashamed
patterns: I harmed myself and now I feel ashamed
responses: You are not alone in feeling this way, and you are not broken. Shame is heavy—but talking to someone can help lighten that burden. You deserve kindness and care.

intents.tag: I feel like no one sees past my disability
patterns: I feel like no one sees past my disability
responses: It’s okay to feel frustrated—your worth goes far beyond what people see. You are not your disability, and you deserve to be valued for your whole self. You're enough.

intents.tag: People treat me like I’m broken
patterns: People treat me like I’m broken
responses: You are not broken. You are whole, valuable, and deserving of love and respect. Anyone who treats you otherwise doesn’t understand your strength.

intents.tag: I hate being dependent on others
patterns: I hate being dependent on others
responses: It’s understandable to want independence. Accepting help doesn't make you weak—it shows courage and adaptability. You are strong in ways others can't imagine.

intents.tag: I'm tired of explaining my condition to people
patterns: I'm tired of explaining my condition to people
responses: That must feel exhausting. You shouldn’t have to justify your existence. Your condition is valid whether others understand it or not. Rest when you need to.
You deserve to be seen, heard, and included. Your existence challenges the world to grow more compassionate. Never forget how important your voice is.

intents.tag: I wish I had a normal life
patterns: I wish I had a normal life
responses: It’s okay to grieve what you’ve lost or never had. But your life still holds meaning, joy, and purpose. You are not alone on this journey.

intents.tag: People talk to my caregiver instead of me
patterns: People talk to my caregiver instead of me
responses: That’s frustrating and hurtful. You deserve respect and direct communication. Your voice matters—don’t hesitate to assert yourself when you're ready.

intents.tag: I feel like a burden to my family
patterns: I feel like a burden to my family
responses: You are not a burden—you’re a human being deserving of care and love. Your presence brings value to your family in more ways than you know.

intents.tag: I get anxious going out in public because of my disability
patterns: I get anxious going out in public because of my disability
responses: That anxiety is valid. You deserve to feel safe and respected in public spaces. Taking small steps and having a support system can help ease that fear.

intents.tag: My disability has changed who I am
patterns: My disability has changed who I am
responses: Change can be painful, but growth can emerge too. You are still you—resilient, valuable, and full of worth. Allow yourself to evolve with kindness.

intents.tag: I feel like I’ll never be loved because of my disability
patterns: I feel like I’ll never be loved because of my disability
responses: That fear is real, but love is not limited to physical ability. You are deeply lovable exactly as you are. The right people will see and cherish your heart.

intents.tag: I lost my job because of my condition
patterns: I lost my job because of my condition
responses: That’s heartbreaking and unfair. You deserve dignity, opportunity, and support. Consider talking to a counselor and looking into advocacy resources that protect your rights.

intents.tag: I don’t know how to cope with my diagnosis
patterns: I don’t know how to cope with my diagnosis
responses: New diagnoses can be overwhelming. Allow yourself to feel, process, and reach out for support—whether through professionals, communities, or loved ones. You're not alone.

intents.tag: I'm constantly in pain and it's wearing me down
patterns: I'm constantly in pain and it's wearing me down
responses: Living with chronic pain is incredibly hard. You are doing your best, and that’s enough. Please consider pain management counseling and self-care support. You deserve relief.

intents.tag: I miss being able to move freely
patterns: I miss being able to move freely
responses: That loss is valid and painful. Grieving your past self is natural. But your current self still holds strength and hope. Be gentle with your heart.

intents.tag: People assume I'm mentally challenged because I'm in a wheelchair
patterns: People assume I'm mentally challenged because I'm in a wheelchair
responses: That ignorance is deeply unfair. Your intelligence, personality, and depth have nothing to do with your mobility. Never let others define your worth.

intents.tag: I hate using assistive devices in public
patterns: I hate using assistive devices in public
responses: It’s okay to feel that way. Remember, using aids isn’t weakness—it’s empowerment. You’re choosing to engage with life, and that’s incredibly brave.
That advocacy is tiring, and you shouldn't have to fight so hard for what should be basic rights. Your efforts matter, and you are making change happen.
Relationships can be challenging for many reasons, but real connections are built on mutual respect and care. You are worthy of love, exactly as you are.

intents.tag: I feel like my identity is just 'disabled'
patterns: I feel like my identity is just 'disabled'
responses: Your identity is so much more. You're a person with passions, thoughts, and dreams. Disability is just one part of your powerful, multifaceted life.

intents.tag: I’m tired of people feeling sorry for me
patterns: I’m tired of people feeling sorry for me
responses: Pity isn't what you need—understanding, respect, and equal treatment are. You deserve to be empowered, not pitied. Your journey is one of resilience.

intents.tag: People doubt my ability to do things
patterns: People doubt my ability to do things
responses: Their doubts don’t define your capabilities. You’ve proven your strength time and again. Keep doing what you know you can—you don’t need their approval.

intents.tag: I feel ashamed of my condition
patterns: I feel ashamed of my condition
responses: You have nothing to be ashamed of. Disability is not a flaw—it's part of the diversity of human experience. You are whole, just as you are.

intents.tag: Every task feels ten times harder than it should
patterns: Every task feels ten times harder than it should
responses: That’s frustrating and exhausting. Your effort is seen and respected. Please remember to rest and ask for help when needed—there’s no shame in that.

intents.tag: I feel left out from my friends
patterns: I feel left out from my friends
responses: Feeling excluded hurts. You deserve inclusion and care. Try expressing your feelings to someone close, or consider connecting with others who truly understand your journey.
Grieving your previous self is valid and important. But remember, your new life can still hold meaning, joy, and strength. Healing takes time—be patient with yourself.

intents.tag: I'm tired of pretending everything's fine
patterns: I'm tired of pretending everything's fine
responses: You don’t have to pretend anymore. Your emotions are real and deserve to be acknowledged. Please consider opening up to someone you trust.
That can feel uncomfortable and isolating. Remember, their stares say more about them than you. Your presence and visibility challenge the world to grow.

intents.tag: Sometimes I wish I just didn’t wake up
patterns: Sometimes I wish I just didn’t wake up
responses: That’s a heavy and painful feeling. Please know there’s help available—talk to a crisis counselor or therapist. You matter deeply and deserve support right now.

intents.tag: I feel like society doesn’t care about people like me
patterns: I feel like society doesn’t care about people like me
responses: It often doesn’t—and that’s unjust. But your existence is powerful and meaningful. Keep speaking up, and know you’re not alone. Change begins with visibility like yours.

intents.tag: I feel like my body betrayed me
patterns: I feel like my body betrayed me
responses: That sense of loss and frustration is completely valid. It’s okay to grieve what once was. But your body is still doing its best to carry you forward—and you’re doing an incredible job surviving.

intents.tag: Everyone pities me, and I hate it
patterns: Everyone pities me, and I hate it
responses: You deserve empathy, not pity. You are strong, capable, and more than your disability. You’re not defined by others' limited perceptions.
Living with a disability can make everyday life feel like a marathon. Rest is not laziness—it’s necessary. You deserve peace and restoration.

intents.tag: I have to work twice as hard to get half the recognition
patterns: I have to work twice as hard to get half the recognition
responses: That’s deeply unfair and disheartening. Your effort is powerful, even if unrecognized. Don’t let the world’s bias erase your brilliance.

intents.tag: My friends are moving on, and I feel left behind
patterns: My friends are moving on, and I feel left behind
responses: That feeling of disconnection is tough. Your path might look different, but it’s still meaningful. True friends will slow down and walk beside you.

intents.tag: No one wants to date someone like me
patterns: No one wants to date someone like me
responses: That’s not true. There are people out there who will love you for exactly who you are. You are lovable and worthy of real connection.

intents.tag: I don't know how to accept my new limitations
patterns: I don't know how to accept my new limitations
responses: Acceptance takes time—it’s okay to struggle. But limitations don’t define your potential. You're still you, and your future still matters.
You’re right—it shouldn’t be this hard. Your frustration is valid. Keep advocating when you can, and lean on communities that fight alongside you.

intents.tag: I hate needing help for basic things
patterns: I hate needing help for basic things
responses: Needing help doesn’t make you weak—it makes you human. Everyone needs support in different ways. You're still strong, still capable, still you.

intents.tag: I'm tired of being inspirational just for existing
patterns: I'm tired of being inspirational just for existing
responses: You shouldn't have to be anyone’s 'inspiration' just for living your life. You deserve to be respected as a person, not as a symbol.

intents.tag: I feel trapped in my own body
patterns: I feel trapped in my own body
responses: That can be one of the hardest feelings. You're doing the best you can in challenging circumstances. Please speak to a therapist if you're struggling with this daily.

intents.tag: People assume my disability defines my intelligence
patterns: People assume my disability defines my intelligence
responses: That assumption is ignorant and hurtful. Your mind is yours—sharp, unique, valuable. Their lack of understanding isn’t your responsibility.

intents.tag: I feel like I’m missing out on everything
patterns: I feel like I’m missing out on everything
responses: That fear of missing out is real, and it hurts. But your experiences are still valid and valuable. You still have purpose and joy ahead of you.

intents.tag: I don't want to be a burden anymore
patterns: I don't want to be a burden anymore
responses: You are *not* a burden. Your presence in this world matters. The people who care about you want to support you. Please hold on.

intents.tag: I’m tired of doctors not listening to me
patterns: I’m tired of doctors not listening to me
responses: You deserve to be heard. Your voice and experiences matter. Advocate when you can, and don’t hesitate to find someone who *will* listen.

intents.tag: I'm losing hope in my future
patterns: I'm losing hope in my future
responses: Hope can be hard to hold, especially when things feel heavy. But your story isn’t over. Talk to someone—there are still beautiful moments ahead.

intents.tag: I hate how people look at me with sympathy
patterns: I hate how people look at me with sympathy
responses: It’s painful when people project weakness onto you. You don’t need sympathy—you deserve dignity, equality, and respect.

intents.tag: Why can't people just treat me normally?
patterns: Why can't people just treat me normally?
responses: You deserve to be seen as a person, not a diagnosis or limitation. You are normal. Society still needs to catch up to your truth.

intents.tag: I feel like I'm always fighting to be seen
patterns: I feel like I'm always fighting to be seen
responses: That fight is exhausting. But you *deserve* to be seen, heard, and included. You’re not alone. We see you.

intents.tag: I’m scared no one will ever understand
patterns: I’m scared no one will ever understand
responses: That fear is heavy—but you’d be surprised. Others are out there who understand exactly how you feel. Don’t stop reaching out.

intents.tag: It feels like everything fun was taken away from me
patterns: It feels like everything fun was taken away from me
responses: Joy may look different now, but it’s not gone forever. Let yourself explore new versions of fun, creativity, and fulfillment.

intents.tag: My disability is getting worse and I feel hopeless
patterns: My disability is getting worse and I feel hopeless
responses: It’s okay to grieve. Please reach out to someone you trust or a professional. There are ways to cope, adapt, and still find light.

intents.tag: I hate how dependent I’ve become
patterns: I hate how dependent I’ve become
responses: It’s okay to hate it. But remember, your value isn’t tied to independence. You're still strong, even when leaning on others.

intents.tag: I feel like I'm just surviving, not living
patterns: I feel like I'm just surviving, not living
responses: That’s such a painful place to be. With support, you can find joy again. Please don’t give up on life—it still has gifts to give.

intents.tag: I get panic attacks because of how people treat me
patterns: I get panic attacks because of how people treat me
responses: That’s real trauma. You’re not overreacting. Please seek trauma-informed therapy if you can—it can help ease the fear and pain.

intents.tag: I’m scared I’ll never be able to do the things I love again
patterns: I’m scared I’ll never be able to do the things I love again
responses: That fear is heartbreaking. But adaptation can open new doors. Don't give up—where there's desire, there’s often a new path.

intents.tag: No one ever asks me how I'm really doing
patterns: No one ever asks me how I'm really doing
responses: Let me ask now: how are you, really? Your emotions matter. You deserve safe spaces where you can open up fully.

intents.tag: People talk down to me like I’m a child
patterns: People talk down to me like I’m a child
responses: That’s demeaning, and you have every right to be angry. Stand tall—your intelligence and dignity deserve full respect.

intents.tag: Even my family doesn't understand my experience
patterns: Even my family doesn't understand my experience
responses: Family misunderstandings can hurt deeply. You deserve emotional connection. Sometimes, chosen family and support groups can offer the understanding we need.

intents.tag: I’m afraid to go outside because of judgment
patterns: I’m afraid to go outside because of judgment
responses: That fear is valid. Try to take small steps, with support if you can. You deserve to take up space—just as you are.

Mental health is a state of well-being in which the individual realizes his or her own abilities, can cope with the normal stresses of life, can work productively and fruitfully, and is able to make a contribution to his or her community
Mental health includes our emotional, psychological, and social well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act. It also helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.

Maintaining mental health is crucial to stabilizing constructive behaviors, emotions, and thoughts. Focusing on mental health care can increase productivity, enhance our self-image, and improve relationships.

intents.tag: What does it mean to have a mental illness?
patterns: What does it mean to have a mental illness?
responses: Mental illnesses are health conditions that disrupt a person's thoughts, emotions, relationships, and daily functioning. They are associated with distress and diminished capacity to engage in the ordinary activities of daily life. Mental illnesses fall along a continuum of severity: some are fairly mild and only interfere with some aspects of life, such as certain phobias. On the other end of the spectrum lie serious mental illnesses, which result in major functional impairment and interference with daily life. These include such disorders as major depression, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder, and may require that the person receives care in a hospital. It is important to know that mental illnesses are medical conditions that have nothing to do with a person's character, intelligence, or willpower. Just as diabetes is a disorder of the pancreas, mental illness is a medical condition due to the brain's biology. Similarly to how one would treat diabetes with medication and insulin, mental illness is treatable with a combination of medication and social support. These treatments are highly effective, with 70-90 percent of individuals receiving treatment experiencing a reduction in symptoms and an improved quality of life. With the proper treatment, it is very possible for a person with mental illness to be independent and successful.

It is estimated that mental illness affects 1 in 5 adults in America, and that 1 in 24 adults have a serious mental illness. Mental illness does not discriminate; it can affect anyone, regardless of gender, age, income, social status, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or background. Although mental illness can affect anyone, certain conditions may be more common in different populations. For instance, eating disorders tend to occur more often in females, while disorders such as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder is more prevalent in children. Additionally, all ages are susceptible, but the young and the old are especially vulnerable. Mental illnesses usually strike individuals in the prime of their lives, with 75 percent of mental health conditions developing by the age of 24. This makes identification and treatment of mental disorders particularly difficult, because the normal personality and behavioral changes of adolescence may mask symptoms of a mental health condition. Parents and caretakers should be aware of this fact, and take notice of changes in their childÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s mood, personality, personal habits, and social withdrawal. When these occur in children under 18, they are referred to as serious emotional disturbances (SEDs).

Parents and caretakers should be aware of this fact, and take notice of changes in their child's mood, personality, personal habits, and social withdrawal. When these occur in children under 18, they are referred to as serious emotional disturbances (SEDs).

intents.tag: What are some of the warning signs of mental illness?
patterns: What are some of the warning signs of mental illness?
responses:
Symptoms of mental health disorders vary depending on the type and severity of the condition. The following is a list of general symptoms that may suggest a mental health disorder, particularly when multiple symptoms are expressed at once. 
 In adults:
 Confused thinking
 Long-lasting sadness or irritability
 Extreme highs and lows in mood
 Excessive fear, worrying, or anxiety
 Social withdrawal
 Dramatic changes in eating or sleeping habits
 Strong feelings of anger
 Delusions or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not really there)
 Increasing inability to cope with daily problems and activities
 Thoughts of suicide
 Denial of obvious problems
 Many unexplained physical problems
 Abuse of drugs and/or alcohol
 
In older children and pre-teens:
 Abuse of drugs and/or alcohol
 Inability to cope with daily problems and activities
 Changes in sleeping and/or eating habits
 Excessive complaints of physical problems
 Defying authority, skipping school, stealing, or damaging property
 Intense fear of gaining weight
 Long-lasting negative mood, often along with poor appetite and thoughts of death
 Frequent outbursts of anger
 
In younger children:
 Changes in school performance
 Poor grades despite strong efforts
 Excessive worrying or anxiety
 Hyperactivity
 Persistent nightmares
 Persistent disobedience and/or aggressive behavior
 Frequent temper tantrums

intents.tag: Can people with mental illness recover?
patterns: Can people with mental illness recover?
responses: When healing from mental illness, early identification and treatment are of vital importance. Based on the nature of the illness, there are a range of effective treatments available. For any type of treatment, it is essential that the person affected is proactive and fully engaged in their own recovery process. Many people with mental illnesses who are diagnosed and treated respond well, although some might experience a return of symptoms. Even in such cases, with careful monitoring and management of the disorder, it is still quite possible to live a fulfilled and productive life.

intents.tag: What should I do if I know someone who appears to have the symptoms of a mental disorder?
patterns: What should I do if I know someone who appears to have the symptoms of a mental disorder?
responses: Although Pandora cannot substitute for professional advice, we encourage those with symptoms to talk to their friends and family members and seek the counsel of a mental health professional. The sooner the mental health condition is identified and treated, the sooner they can get on the path to recovery. If you know someone who is having problems, don't assume that the issue will resolve itself. Let them know that you care about them, and that there are treatment options available that will help them heal. Speak with a mental health professional or counselor if you think your friend or family member is experiencing the symptoms of a mental health condition. If the affected loved one knows that you support them, they will be more likely to seek out help.

intents.tag: How can I find a mental health professional for myself or my child?
patterns: How can I find a mental health professional for myself or my child?
responses: Feeling comfortable with the professional you or your child is working with is critical to the success of the treatment. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require research. Start by searching for providers in your area.

Just as there are different types of medications for physical illness, different treatment options are available for individuals with mental illness. Treatment works differently for different people. It is important to find what works best for you or your child.

intents.tag: If I become involved in treatment, what do I need to know?
patterns: If I become involved in treatment, what do I need to know?
responses:
Since beginning treatment is a big step for individuals and families, it can be very overwhelming. It is important to be as involved and engaged in the treatment process as possible. Some questions you will need to have answered include:
 What is known about the cause of this particular illness?
 Are there other diagnoses where these symptoms are common?
 Do you normally include a physical or neurological examination?
 Are there any additional tests or exams that you would recommend at this point?
 Would you advise an independent opinion from another psychiatrist at this point?
 What program of treatment is the most helpful with this diagnosis?
 Will this program involve services by other specialists? If so, who will be responsible for coordinating these services?
 What do you see as the family's role in this program of treatment?
 How much access will the family have to the individuals who are providing the treatment?
 What medications are generally used with this diagnosis?
 How much experience do you have in treating individuals with this illness?
 What can I do to help you in the treatment?

intents.tag: What is the difference between mental health professionals?
patterns: What is the difference between mental health professionals?
responses: There are many types of mental health professionals. The variety of providers and their services may be confusing. Each have various levels of education, training, and may have different areas of expertise. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require some research.

intents.tag: How can I find a mental health professional right for my child or myself?
patterns: How can I find a mental health professional right for my child or myself?
responses: Feeling comfortable with the professional you or your child is working with is critical to the success of your treatment. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require some research.

intents.tag: Where else can I get help?
patterns: Where else can I get help?
responses: Where you go for help will depend on the nature of the problem and/or symptoms and what best fits you. Often, the best place to start is by talking with someone you trust about your concerns, such as a family member, friend, clergy, healthcare provider, or other professionals. Having this social support is essential in healing from mental illness, and you will be able to ask them for referrals or recommendations for trusted mental health practitioners. Search for mental health resources in your area. Secondly, there are people and places throughout the country that provide services to talk, to listen, and to help you on your journey to recovery. Thirdly, many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members, and friends. Some support groups are peer led while others may be led by a mental health professional.

intents.tag: What should I know before starting a new medication?
patterns: What should I know before starting a new medication?
responses:
The best source of information regarding medications is the physician prescribing them. He or she should be able to answer questions such as:    
1. What is the medication supposed to do? 
2. When should it begin to take effect, and how will I know when it is effective? 
3. How is the medication taken and for how long? What food, drinks, other medicines, and activities should be avoided while taking this medication? 
4. What are the side effects and what should be done if they occur? 
5. What do I do if a dose is missed? 
6. Is there any written information available about this medication? 
7. Are there other medications that might be appropriate? 
8. If so, why do you prefer the one you have chosen? 
9. How do you monitor medications and what symptoms indicate that they should be raised, lowered, or changed? 
10. All medications should be taken as directed. Most medications for mental illnesses do not work when taken irregularly, and extra doses can cause severe, sometimes dangerous side effects. Many psychiatric medications begin to have a beneficial effect only after they have been taken for several weeks.

intents.tag: Where can I go to find therapy?
patterns: Where can I go to find therapy?
responses: Different kinds of therapy are more effective based on the nature of the mental health condition and/or symptoms and the person who has them (for example, children will benefit from a therapist who specializes in childrenâ€™s mental health). However, there are several different types of treatment and therapy that can help.

intents.tag: Where can I learn about types of mental health treatment?
patterns: Where can I learn about types of mental health treatment?
responses: Mental health conditions are often treated with medication, therapy or a combination of the two. However, there are many different types of treatment available, including Complementary & Alternative Treatments, self-help plans, and peer support. Treatments are very personal and should be discussed by the person with the mental health conditions and his or her team.

intents.tag: What are the different types of mental health professionals?
patterns: What are the different types of mental health professionals?
responses: There are many types of mental health professionals. Finding the right one for you may require some research.

intents.tag: Where can I go to find a support group?
patterns: Where can I go to find a support group?
responses: Many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members and friends. Some support groups are peer-led, while others may be led by a mental health professional.

intents.tag: Can you prevent mental health problems?
patterns: Can you prevent mental health problems?
responses: We can all suffer from mental health challenges, but developing our wellbeing, resilience, and seeking help early can help prevent challenges becoming serious.

intents.tag: Are there cures for mental health problems?
patterns: Are there cures for mental health problems?
responses: It is often more realistic and helpful to find out what helps with the issues you face. Talking, counselling, medication, friendships, exercise, good sleep and nutrition, and meaningful occupation can all help.

intents.tag: is there any cure for mental health problems?
patterns: is there any cure for mental health problems?
responses: It is often more realistic and helpful to find out what helps with the issues you face. Talking, counselling, medication, friendships, exercise, good sleep and nutrition, and meaningful occupation can all help.
Challenges or problems with your mental health can arise from psychological, biological, and social, issues, as well as life events.

intents.tag: What do I do if I'm worried about my mental health?
patterns: What do I do if I'm worried about my mental health?
responses: The most important thing is to talk to someone you trust. This might be a friend, colleague, family member, or GP. In addition to talking to someone, it may be useful to find out more information about what you are experiencing. These things may help to get some perspective on what you are experiencing, and be the start of getting help.

intents.tag: How do I know if I'm unwell?
patterns: How do I know if I'm unwell?
responses: If your beliefs , thoughts , feelings or behaviours have a significant impact on your ability to function in what might be considered a normal or ordinary way, it would be important to seek help.

intents.tag: How can I maintain social connections? What if I feel lonely?
patterns: How can I maintain social connections? What if I feel lonely?
responses: A lot of people are alone right now, but we don't have to be lonely. We're all in this together. Think about the different ways to connect that are most meaningful for you. For example, you might prefer a video chat over a phone call, or you might prefer to text throughout the day rather than one set time for a video call. Then, work with your social networks to make a plan. You might video chat with your close friends in the evening and phone a family member once a week. Remember to be mindful of people who may not be online. Check in by phone and ask how you can help. The quality of your social connections matter. Mindlessly scrolling through social media and liking a few posts usually doesn't build strong social connections. Make sure you focus on strategies that actually make you feel included and connected. If your current strategies don't help you feel connected, problem-solve to see if you can find a solution. Everyone feels lonely at times. Maybe you recently moved to a new city, are changing your circle of friends, lost someone important in your life, or lost your job and also lost important social connections with coworkers. Other people may have physical connections to others but may feel like their emotional or social needs aren't met. Measures like social distancing or self-isolation can make loneliness feel worse no matter why you feel lonely now. Reach out to the connections you do have. Suggest ways to keep in touch and see if you can set a regular time to connect. People may hesitate to reach out for a lot of different reasons, so don't be afraid to be the one who asks. Look for local community support groups and mutual aid groups on social media. This pandemic is bringing everyone together, so look for opportunities to make new connections. These groups are a great way to share your skills and abilities or seek help and support. Look for specialized support groups. Support groups are moving online, and there are a lot of different support lines to call if you need to talk to someone.

intents.tag: What's the difference between anxiety and stress?
patterns: What's the difference between anxiety and stress?
responses: Stress and anxiety are often used interchangeably, and there is overlap between stress and anxiety. Stress is related to the same fight, flight, or freeze response as anxiety, and the physical sensations of anxiety and stress may be very similar. The cause of stress and anxiety are usually different, however. Stress focuses on mainly external pressures on us that we're finding hard to cope with. When we are stressed, we usually know what we're stressed about, and the symptoms of stress typically disappear after the stressful situation is over. Anxiety, on the other hand, isn't always as easy to figure out. Anxiety focuses on worries or fears about things that could threaten us, as well as anxiety about the anxiety itself. Stress and anxiety are both part of being human, but both can be problems if they last for a long time or have an impact on our well-being or daily life.

intents.tag: What's the difference between sadness and depression?
patterns: What's the difference between sadness and depression?
responses: Sadness is a normal reaction to a loss, disappointment, problems, or other difficult situations. Feeling sad from time to time is just another part of being human. In these cases, feelings of sadness go away quickly and you can go about your daily life. Other ways to talk about sadness might be feeling low, feeling down, or feeling blue.A person may say they are feeling depressed, but if it goes away on its own and doesn't impact life in a big way, it probably isn't the illness of depression. Depression is a mental illness that affects your mood, the way you understand yourself, and the way you understand and relate to things around you. It can also go by different names, such as clinical depression, major depressive disorder, or major depression. Depression can come up for no reason, and it lasts for a long time. It's much more than sadness or low mood. People who experience depression may feel worthless or hopeless. They may feel unreasonable guilty. Some people may experience depression as anger or irritability. It may be hard to concentrate or make decisions. Most people lose interest in things that they used to enjoy and may isolate themselves from others. There are also physical signs of depression, such as problems with sleep, appetite and energy and unexplainable aches or pains. Some may experience difficult thoughts about death or ending their life (suicide). Depression lasts longer than two weeks, doesn't usually go away on its own, and impacts your life. It's a real illness, and it is very treatable. It's important to seek help if you're concerned about depression.

In these cases, feelings of sadness go away quickly and you can go about your daily life. Most people lose interest in things that they used to enjoy and may isolate themselves from others. Some may experience difficult thoughts about death or ending their life (suicide). Depression lasts longer than two weeks, doesn't usually go away on its own, and impacts your life. depression is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. also called major depressive disorder or clinical depression, it affects how you feel, think and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.

intents.tag: what are the causes of depression?
patterns: what are the causes of depression?
responses: it's complicated, and there are multiple causes of major depression. factors such as genetic vulnerability, severe life stressors, substances you may take (some medications, drugs and alcohol) and medical conditions can affect the way your brain regulates your moods.

intents.tag: what are the top causes of depression?
patterns: what are the top causes of depression?
responses: abuse. past physical, sexual, or emotional abuse can increase the vulnerability to clinical depression later in life.

intents.tag: which age group has the highest rate of depression?
patterns: which age group has the highest rate of depression?
responses: this number represented 7.1% of all u.s. adults. the prevalence of major depressive episode was higher among adult females (8.7%) compared to males (5.3%). the prevalence of adults with a major depressive episode was highest among individuals aged 18-25 (13.1%).

intents.tag: which country has the highest rate of depression?
patterns: which country has the highest rate of depression?
responses: the most depressed country is afghanistan, where more than one in five people suffer from the disorder. the least depressed is japan, with a diagnosed rate of less than 2.5 percent.

intents.tag: which country has the lowest rate of depression?
patterns: which country has the lowest rate of depression?
responses: the most depressed country is afghanistan, where more than one in five people suffer from the disorder. the least depressed is japan, with a diagnosed rate of less than 2.5 percent.

intents.tag: is school a cause of depression?
patterns: is school a cause of depression?
responses: not only does school sometimes contribute to depression, depression can also interfere with school. moreover, research shows that 75 percent of all mental health conditions begin by age 24. hence, the college years are a critical time for understanding and talking about teen mental health.

intents.tag: what is the biological cause of depression?
patterns: what is the biological cause of depression?
responses: there is no single cause for depression; rather it's a combination of stress and a person's vulnerability to developing depression. the predisposition to developing depression can be inherited. other biological causes for depression can include physical illness, the process of ageing and gender.

intents.tag: how does depression affect the world?
patterns: how does depression affect the world?
responses: depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide and is a major contributor to the overall global burden of disease. more women are affected by depression than men. depression can lead to suicide. there are effective psychological and pharmacological treatments for moderate and severe depression.

intents.tag: which race has the highest rate of depression?
patterns: which race has the highest rate of depression?
responses: major depression was most prevalent among hispanics (10.8%), followed by african americans (8.9%) and whites (7.8%). the odds of depressive disorders among older hispanics were 44% greater than among whites (or = 1.44; 95% ci = 1.02, 2.04), representing a significantly greater prevalence of major depression.

intents.tag: what is the meaning of anxiety and depression?
patterns: what is the meaning of anxiety and depression?
responses: depression and anxiety disorders are different, but people with depression often experience symptoms similar to those of an anxiety disorder, such as nervousness, irritability, and problems sleeping and concentrating. but each disorder has its own causes and its own emotional and behavioral symptoms.
it's important to remember that oversleeping is a possible symptom of depression and that oversleeping doesn't cause depression. but it can exacerbate and worsen depression symptoms

intents.tag: can lack of sleep make you feel sad?
patterns: can lack of sleep make you feel sad?
responses: studies show people who are sleep deprived report increases in negative moods (anger, frustration, irritability, sadness) and decreases in positive moods. and sleeplessness is often a symptom of mood disorders, such as depression and anxiety.

intents.tag: is depression a side effect of diabetes?
patterns: is depression a side effect of diabetes?
responses: if you have diabetes — either type 1 or type 2 — you have an increased risk of developing depression. and if you're depressed, you may have a greater chance of developing type 2 diabetes. the good news is that diabetes and depression can be treated together.

intents.tag: can low blood sugar cause suicidal thoughts?
patterns: can low blood sugar cause suicidal thoughts?
responses: the observed association between plasma glucose levels, insulin resistance and suicidal behaviour suggests that disturbances in glucose metabolism are associated with suicidal ideation and attempts.

anxiety attacks usually peak within 10 minutes, and they rarely last more than 30 minutes. but during that short time, you may experience terror so severe that you feel as if you're about to die or totally lose control.

intents.tag: what are the stages of anxiety?
patterns: what are the stages of anxiety?
responses: anxiety levels are typically classified by the level of distress and impairment experienced into four categories namely, mild anxiety, moderate anxiety, severe anxiety and panic level anxiety.

intents.tag: at what age does anxiety peak?
patterns: at what age does anxiety peak?
responses: adults ages 30 to 44 have the highest rate of anxiety of this age group, with around 23% of people this age reporting an anxiety disorder within the past year.

intents.tag: why is anxiety bad for you?
patterns: why is anxiety bad for you?
responses: anxiety disorders can cause rapid heart rate, palpitations, and chest pain. you may also be at an increased risk of high blood pressure and heart disease. if you already have heart disease, anxiety disorders may raise the risk of coronary events.

intents.tag: what is the 3 3 3 rule for anxiety?
patterns: what is the 3 3 3 rule for anxiety?
responses: there's an anxiety-reducing technique called grounding. there are different versions of this, but an easy one to remember is the 3-3-3 rule. mentally note three things you see, three sounds you hear, and then move three parts of your body. this exercise can help your mind refocus on something else.

we are aware of a tiny fraction of the thinking that goes on in our minds, and we can control only a tiny part of our conscious thoughts. the vast majority of our thinking efforts goes on subconsciously. ... slips of the tongue and accidental actions offer glimpses of our unfiltered subconscious mental life.

patterns: how many thoughts a day do we have?
responses: a new study has suggested that an average person has 6,200 thoughts per day. thousands of thoughts cross our mind through the day. many people even complain that they can't sleep immediately after going to bed as their brain does not stop thinking.

intents.tag: What does it mean to have a mental illness? (2)
patterns: What does it mean to have a mental illness? (2)
responses: Mental illnesses are health conditions that disrupt a person's thoughts, emotions, relationships, and daily functioning. They are associated with distress and diminished capacity to engage in the ordinary activities of daily life. Mental illnesses fall along a continuum of severity: some are fairly mild and only interfere with some aspects of life, such as certain phobias. On the other end of the spectrum lie serious mental illnesses, which result in major functional impairment and interference with daily life. These include such disorders as major depression, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder, and may require that the person receives care in a hospital. It is important to know that mental illnesses are medical conditions that have nothing to do with a person's character, intelligence, or willpower. Just as diabetes is a disorder of the pancreas, mental illness is a medical condition due to the brain's biology. Similarly to how one would treat diabetes with medication and insulin, mental illness is treatable with a combination of medication and social support. These treatments are highly effective, with 70-90 percent of individuals receiving treatment experiencing a reduction in symptoms and an improved quality of life. With the proper treatment, it is very possible for a person with mental illness to be independent and successful.

It is estimated that mental illness affects 1 in 5 adults in America, and that 1 in 24 adults have a serious mental illness. Mental illness does not discriminate; it can affect anyone, regardless of gender, age, income, social status, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or background. Although mental illness can affect anyone, certain conditions may be more common in different populations. For instance, eating disorders tend to occur more often in females, while disorders such as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder is more prevalent in children. Additionally, all ages are susceptible, but the young and the old are especially vulnerable. Mental illnesses usually strike individuals in the prime of their lives, with 75 percent of mental health conditions developing by the age of 24. This makes identification and treatment of mental disorders particularly difficult, because the normal personality and behavioral changes of adolescence may mask symptoms of a mental health condition. Parents and caretakers should be aware of this fact, and take notice of changes in their childÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s mood, personality, personal habits, and social withdrawal. When these occur in children under 18, they are referred to as serious emotional disturbances (SEDs).
